title: Herpesvirus infection reduces Pol II occupancy of host promoters but spares
body:
Regulating messenger RNA (mRNA) abundance is of central importance during both 43 cellular homeostasis and disease. While it is intuitive that transcriptional changes in the nucleus 44 impact RNA levels in the cytoplasm, evidence in both yeast and mammalian cells now indicates 45 that the converse is also true: altered cytoplasmic mRNA decay rates can broadly impact 46 transcription by RNA polymerase II (Pol II). As a control, we also infected cells with a version of MHV68 containing the 97 point mutation R443I in the viral muSOX endonuclease gene, which reduces its mRNA cleavage 98 activity. R443I retains a similar lytic cycle and infectious capability to wildtype (WT) MHV68 in 99 vivo and in vitro its infectious capability is similar to MHV68 in mouse fibroblasts (6,23). 100

MHV68-infected cells displayed promoter-proximal loss of Pol II at 86% of loci compared to 101 mock-infected cells, averaged across two biological replicates and subtracting input signal (Fig 102 1A and S1 Fig A) . Loss of Pol II occupancy was primarily due to muSOX-induced mRNA 103 decay, as this signal loss either did not occur or was reduced at 67% of these loci during 104 infection with R443I MHV68 (Fig 1A and S1 Fig A) . Sixty-three genes, or 1.3% of loci, showed 105

We 108 independently validated the ChIP-seq results by ChIP-qPCR at the Rplp0 and Fus promoters, 109 both of which showed a significant reduction of Pol II occupancy in cells infected with WT but 110 not R443I MHV68 (Fig 1C) , as did a validation using a second antibody that recognizes the N-111 terminus of the major subunit of Pol II, Rpb1 (Fig1D). The genome-wide reduction in poised Pol 112 II in WT but not R443I infected cells was also evident when the sequencing reads from positions 113 -2000 to +4000 around the transcription start sites (TSS) were plotted as a histogram (Fig 1G and  114   S1 Fig B) . The variability between replicates in R443I recovery (Fig 1B) is likely due to 115 differences in the extent of host shutoff reduction between replicates due to R443I reducing 116 muSOX activity while not being a catalytic mutant. 117

To assess the stage of transcription impacted by RNA decay, we compared the amount of 118

Pol II in promoter regions (-50 to +200) and the amount of Pol II in gene bodies (+200 to +5000) 119 between mock and infected samples. Consistent with the above analyses, MHV68 infected cells 120 contained markedly less promoter proximal Pol II than uninfected cells, and this signal was 121 partially recovered in the R443I infection ( Fig 1E) . Genes with impaired Pol II promoter binding 122 during MHV68 infection also had less Pol II within the gene body compared to mock infected 123 cells, which again was not observed during R443I infection ( Fig 1F) . Notably, the difference in 124 regression line slopes between MHV68 and mock infected cells was clearly more marked when 125 comparing Pol II promoter occupancy, suggesting that the primary transcriptional defect is at the 126 stage of initiation. This is consistent with data from previous studies that found no defect in 127 serine 2 phosphorylation of elongating Pol II and no consistent change to Pol II elongation 128 during MHV68 infection (22, 24) . 129

Finally, to assess if RNA decay affected transcription termination, we plotted sequencing 130 reads between 1kb upstream and 1kb downstream of the transcription termination site (TTS) as a 131 histogram ( Fig 1H and S1 Fig D) . To confirm that viral promoters integrated into the host genome were also repressed in 186 the context of infection, we infected MC57G cells containing an integrated MHV68 M4 187 promoter-driven puromycin cassette with MHV68. Indeed, the M4 promoter was repressed to a 188 similar degree as host Fus and Rplp0 promoters during infection with WT MHV68 but not the 189 mRNA decay-deficient MHV68 R443I (Fig 4C) . In summary, these data argue against the promoter is strongly repressed during muSOX-induced mRNA decay. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/585984 doi: bioRxiv preprint Finally, we evaluated whether the lytic stage of infection was necessary to confer escape 208 from transcriptional repression, or whether some other feature of the non-replicating viral 209 genome was important. To this end, we examined Pol II occupancy at promoters of several genes 210 expressed from the KSHV genome during latent infection in 293T cells, when the viral DNA is 211 maintained as an episome but not amplified in replication compartments. Latent infection does 212 not promote mRNA turnover, and thus we transfected muSOX into these cells to stimulate 213 mRNA turnover in the absence of lytic replication. Similar to the host genes Gapdh and Rplp0, 214

we observed an RNA decay-induced repression of Pol II occupancy at the latent viral promoter 215 LANA while the viral K1 promoter was repressed in 4 out of 5 experiments ( Fig 5D) . We also 216 observed repression of the human Ef1a promoter, which is present on the KSHV viral episome 217 as a driver of the GFP reporter gene (Fig 5D) . Across the host genome, Pol II appears to be most strongly affected at the stage of 232 recruitment. The reduction in promoter-proximal Pol II is propagated into the gene body, 233 although the differences there were less pronounced, suggesting that once transcription of a gene 234 initiates there are not subsequent blocks to elongation. This agrees with prior studies of 235 individual host loci in MHV68 infected or muSOX expressing cells (22,24). The population of 236

Pol II that is promoter-proximal and measured during a ChIP experiment has been shown to 237 comprise a combination of actively engaged Pol II as well as Pol II transiently binding to the 238 DNA. Thus, a large reduction in promoter-proximal Pol II may not be expected to be borne out 239 in the gene body (32). Additionally, the antibody we use in this study binds with higher affinity 240 to hypophosphorylated Pol II(33), likely affecting our ability to pull down elongating and 241 phosphorylated forms of Pol II. We also did not observe a defect in transcription termination, or 242 evidence of polymerases on the DNA after TTSs, suggesting that the gammaherpesvirus MHV68 243 does not induce the termination defect and run-on transcription of host genes recently described 244 in HSV-1 (34). 245

Two pieces of evidence indicate that reduction of Pol II at host genes is unlikely due to 246 sequestration of or competition for the transcription machinery by the viral DNA. First, infection 247 with the mRNA decay mutant virus R443I, which replicates its viral genome to WT levels (6), 248 does not induce the widespread reduction in Pol II recruitment to host promoters. Second, 249 transfection of muSOX alone (or other broad acting viral endonucleases) in the absence of viral 250 infection is sufficient to induce transcriptional repression at host promoters. Therefore, we 251 instead favor the hypothesis that one or more cellular proteins released from degrading mRNA 252 . In conclusion, decay-coupled transcriptional repression is a novel facet of viral 299 manipulation of the cellular gene expression landscape. We hypothesize that the ability to escape 300 from transcriptional repression is linked to the open conformation of viral DNA in replication 301 compartments, and that this helps these viruses counteract decay-induced viral transcript loss. 302

While widespread mRNA decay has been shown to facilitate immune evasion, gene expression 303 control, and latency establishment, the robust viral transcription we document here presents a 304 parsimonious explanation for a novel way in which the virus benefits from accelerated decay. buffer. MHV68 was produced by first making p0 virus by transfecting NIH 3T3 cells 362 in 6-well plates with 2.5 µg BAC DNA using TransIT-X2 (Mirus Bio) for 24h. Five to seven 363 days later, the cells were split into a 10 cm dish, then harvested and frozen. After 5-7 days the 364 majority of cells showed cytopathic effect (CPE). 30 µL of p0 was then added per confluent 10 365 cm dish of NIH 3T12 cells, split 2 days later into four 10 cm dishes and harvested 4-6 days later 366 when all cells were infected.
